title: Identify Negation Functions
instruction: Identify the function of the negation particle in each sentence from classical Buddhist texts.

questions.question: What does མི do in: གཟུགས་མི་སྐྱེ་མི་འགག (Form does not arise, does not cease) [Heart Sutra]
questions.english: Form does not arise, does not cease.

options.transliteration: མི negates སྐྱེ (arise) and འགག (cease) — both present verbs
Past negation uses མ, not མི
Existence negation uses མེད
Prohibitions use མ, not མི

questions.hint: སྐྱེ and འགག are present tense verbs. མི is placed before them.

questions.question: What is the function of མེད in: མིག་མེད། རྣ་བ་མེད། སྣ་མེད། (No eyes, no ears, no nose.) [Heart Sutra]
questions.transliteration: mig med rna ba med sna med
questions.english: No eyes, no ears, no nose.

options.text: Negates existence of each sense organ
options.transliteration: མེད negates ཡོད — these sense organs do not exist (in emptiness)

options.text: Negates identity of each sense organ
options.transliteration: Identity negation uses མིན, not མེད
Present tense negation uses མི
Prohibitions use མ before a verb

questions.hint: མེད is the negative of ཡོད (to exist). What is being negated here?

questions.question: What does མ do in: ཉོན་མོངས་ཀྱི་དབང་དུ་མ་སོང༌། (Do not fall under the power of the afflictions!) [37 Practices]
questions.transliteration: nyon mongs kyi dbang du ma song
questions.english: Do not fall under the power of the afflictions!

options.transliteration: མ before imperative སོང = prohibition 'don't go!'
མ can negate past verbs, but here it is a command
Existence negation uses མེད
Present negation uses མི, not མ

questions.hint: སོང is the imperative of འགྲོ (to go). མ before an imperative means...

questions.question: What does the double negation express in: ཆོས་རྣམས་བདེན་པ་མིན། རྫུན་པ་ཡང་མིན། (Phenomena are not true, nor false.)
questions.transliteration: chos rnams bden pa min rdzun pa yang min
questions.english: Phenomena are not true, nor are they false.

options.text: The Middle Way — beyond both extremes
options.transliteration: Neither true nor false = neither eternalism nor nihilism
The text explicitly says they are NOT false either
The double negation does not affirm existence

options.text: Nothing can be known about phenomena
options.transliteration: This is not skepticism but the Middle Way view

questions.hint: Buddhist logic uses double negation to avoid both extremes of eternalism and nihilism.

questions.question: Which pair correctly matches the negation particle to what it negates?
questions.english: Match the negation particle to its function.

options.text: མིན negates ཡིན, མེད negates ཡོད
options.transliteration: མིན (is not) negates ཡིན (is); མེད (not exist) negates ཡོད (exists)

options.text: མིན negates ཡོད, མེད negates ཡིན
options.transliteration: This is reversed — མིན goes with ཡིན, མེད with ཡོད

options.text: མི negates ཡིན, མ negates ཡོད
options.transliteration: མི/མ negate verbs, not auxiliaries ཡིན/ཡོད

options.text: མེད negates ཡིན, མིན negates past verbs
options.transliteration: མིན negates ཡིན (identity), not past verbs

questions.hint: ཡིན means 'to be' (identity), ཡོད means 'to exist'. Each has its own negative form.

correctFeedback: Excellent! You understand the four negation particles and their distinct functions in classical Tibetan.
incorrectFeedback: Review the four negation particles: མི (present/future verbs), མ (past verbs + prohibitions), མིན (negates ཡིན — identity), མེད (negates ཡོད — existence).
